Preservative Methylisothiazolinone (MI) is a preservative. MI was initially used occupationally , in paints, adhesives/glues and cleaners , , as a mixture with methylchloroisothiazolinone (MCI). Since 2005, it has been widely used in cosmetics and household products , such as moist wipes, shampoos, cleaners, and liquid laundry products. When used in the industrial setting, MI was thought not to be a significant occupational allergen. Subsequently, following extensive domestic use, MI was found to be a strong allergen. It was responsible for an 'epidemic' of contact allergic dermatitis (2016). MI was named Contact Allergen of the Year in 2013 by the American Contact Dermatitis Society.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of fever, and joint and back pain develops hyperpigmentation over the nose after 5 days of taking NSAIDs. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chikungunya The given clinical scenario with Centro- facial pigmentation involving the nose with history of fever, joint and back pain is suggestive of Chikungunya - chick sign.

Highyeild:

Chikungunya (CHK): Acute febrile illness accompanied by a rash, joint, and muscle pain caused by an arthropod-borne alphavirus. Vector: Aedes Mosquito Incubation periods: 4 to 7 days Features: sudden-onset high fever and chills followed by severe polyarthralgia . symmetrical involvement of several joints, especially the small joints of the hands and feet. arthralgia may persist for several months. Cutaneous features: An erythematous macular or maculopapular rash usually appears in the first 2–3 days of the illness and subsides within 7–10 days The rash may result in post-inflammatory macules or diffuse pigmentation. Pigmentation is most common on the face, characteristically affecting the nose : chick sign Treatment: Rehydration Topical emollients

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Melanoma: It is a common skin cancer that is characterized by unusual-looking freckles or moles and may itch or bleed. Option B. Fixed drug eruption: It is a dermatological manifestation of drug reactions that often occur in the same location upon re-exposure to a drug. The hands and feet, eyelids, and anogenital areas are common sites. Lesions in the oral mucosa are usually found on the lips, tongue, and hard palate. Option C. Dengue : Rash in dengue fever is a maculopapular or macular confluent rash over the face, thorax, and flexor surfaces, with islands of skin sparing. The rash typically begins on day 3 and persists for 2-3 days. A second rash may occur within 1-2 days of defervescence, lasting 1-5 days; it is morbilliform, is maculopapular, spares the palms and soles, and occasionally desquamates.

questions.text: A male child born to a non-consanguineous couple has blisters associated with friction. The couple had a child who had a similar condition and died within a few weeks of birth. What is the condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epidermolysis bullosa The given clinical scenario with a history of blister at the site of trauma is suggestive of Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita. It is a clinically heterogeneous subepidermal blistering disease defined by autoantibodies against type VII collagen. Clinical characteristics are skin fragility, erosions, blisters, crusts, and scars on trauma‐prone areas such as the hands, knuckles, elbows, knees, and toes. Scarring alopecia and nail loss may occur. Both the classic and the inflammatory forms may coexist in the same patient and the clinical presentation of a given EBA patient may change during the disease course.

Highyeild:

Direct immunofluorescence findings in common bullous disorders Pemphigus Vulgaris Fishnet appearance- Epidermal intercellular deposits of C3 with a reticular pattern Pemphigus Foliaceous Fishnet appearance Bullous pemphigoid Linear deposits of IgG on the dermal-epidermal junction in bullous pemphigoid Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita Linear deposits of IgG on the dermal-epidermal junction zone, with a u-serrated pattern

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Neonatal pemphigus : It is an autoimmune blistering disease caused by the transfer of maternal IgG (against desmoglein-3), through the placenta, when the mother is affected by pemphigus characterized by blistering of the skin and in some cases, the mucosal surfaces, such as the inside of the mouth, nose, throat, eyes, and genitals. The blisters are fragile and tend to burst, causing crusty sores. Option B. Congenital syphilis: It is caused by the transmission of the spirochete Treponema pallidum from the mother to the fetus.Morphologically, any type of skin lesion, including bullous lesions can occur. Fissuring of lips, angles of mouth, and nasolabial folds. Option C. Chronic bullous disease of childhood: It is a rare autoimmune skin condition which results in clusters of blisters developing in rings often on the face or genitals. New bullae develop around healing bulla (a string of pearl appearance)

questions.text: A Young female came with a complaint of a bizarrely shaped lesion over her face as shown in the image. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dermatitis Artefacta The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Dermatitis artefacta. Aka “factitial dermatitis”. It is a condition in which skin lesions are solely produced or inflicted by the patient's own actions . The lesions that are difficult to recognize and do not conform to those of known dermatoses Risk factors: Underlying psychological problems are often associated. It could be a form of emotional release in situations of distress or part of attention-seeking behavior. More common in teenage females Features of dermatitis artefacta The lesions that are difficult to recognize and do not conform to those of known dermatoses Bizarre shapes with irregular outlines in a linear or geometric pattern. clearly demarcated f rom surrounding normal skin. It can present as red patches, swelling, blisters, denuded areas, crusts, cuts, burns, and scars. Lesions do not evolve gradually but emerge almost overnight without any prior signs or symptoms. They are usually found on sites that are readily accessible to the patient's hands, e.g. face, hands, arms, or legs.

Vitiligo: It is an acquired, chronic, depigmenting disorder of the skin, in which melanocytes that determine the colour of skin, hair, and eyes are progressively lost. It appears as milky-white patches of skin (leukoderma). Option D. Insect bite: It can either present as a localized reaction which causes swelling, itchy papules or can cause anaphylaxis.
